results.title: Doc the Destroyer  for Commodore 64 & 128
results.creator_credit: Geoff Evans, Paul Kidd, Melbourne House and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and manual booklet in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Doc the Destroyer [computer game]. Doc the Destroyer is a side view, strategy arcade adventure in a post apocalyptic setting for one player. At the start of the game, players are given 60 points which they can distribute between five statistics Strength, Endurance, Intelligence, Luck and Charisma. As Doc, players are presented with various choices that determine your next action and some will throw the player into arcade styled combat.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoff Evans, Paul Kidd, Melbourne House and Beam Software

results.title: Do you think you can manage? (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Darlow, Robert Reid and Video Arts
results.brief_description: A training film for office supervisors and their managers. Explores in personal and human terms the problems which can arise when a clerk is promoted, unprepared for a supervisory job, and suggests some basic and simple methods by which they can be avoided.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Darlow, Robert Reid and Video Arts

results.title: Do you remember?
results.creator_credit: Tony Thompson and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: Day in, day out, throughout the year, the passengers on London’s buses and Underground leave behind them enough property to keep a large staff of sorters and storemen permanently busy. How the lost property is collected, sorted, ware-housed and, in most cases, restored to owners is the story of this film.
results.description: Day in, day out, throughout the year, the passengers on London’s buses and Underground leave behind them enough property to keep a large staff of sorters and storemen permanently busy. results.title: Do you mind if I smoke?
results.creator_credit: Sue Woodford and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Investigates the dangers of passive smoking, ie the smoke inhaled by a non-smoker from cigarettes left burning in an ashtray or in someone’s hand. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Do you ever wonder?
results.creator_credit: Jerry Harned, Gary Baker and Johnson-Nyquist Productions
results.brief_description: A film exploring the identity problems faced by young people built around four soft rock songs, which provide the only commentary. A father, trying to bridge the generation gap, attempts to reach an understanding with his son; a young girl trying to find herself, asks if anyone would care if she resigned from the human race; and the final segment, performed by a mime, illustrates how people build walls around themselves.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jerry Harned, Gary Baker and Johnson-Nyquist Productions

results.title: Do we really want to live this way?
results.creator_credit: Marty Ostrow, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines the pollution problems associated with the world’s most affluent societies and includes case studies of air quality in Los Angeles and water quality in the Rhine River Basin. Narrated by Karina Kelly. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Do unto others
results.brief_description: Courtesy and civilised personal behaviour as the basis of road safety. How bullying, rudeness and impatience set up a series of dangerous chain reactions; various road situations showing the danger of the driver’s sense of power, and the need for courtesy as a complement to modern highway design. The risks to pedestrians, especially the old and very young. An old blind man and a schoolboy provide a story thread.
